Solution to Question 18:
In the given vertex presentation, the fetal position is right occipitoanterior.
Fetal position refers to the relation of the denominator (arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part), with respect to different quadrants of the maternal pelvis. In vertex presentation, the denominator is taken as the occiput (which is close to the triangular posterior fontanelle).
To determine the fetal position the following two steps are followed:
Determine the direction in which the occiput is facing:
Towards the pubic symphysis - occipito-anterior
Towards the sacral promontory - occipito-posterior
Midway between pubic symphysis and sacral promontory - occipito-transverse
Determine if the occiput is facing the left or the right in relation to the materal pelvis





Solution to Question 19:
Uterine contractions are palpable when the intensity is >10 mmHg.

Uterine contractions cause cervical dilatation at 15 mmHg and are painful beyond 15 mmHg. Units for measuring the intensity of uterine contractions are mmHg and Montevideo units (MV). 1 MV = intensity of uterine contractions x number of contractions in 10 min.
During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time of delivery, it is 300 MV.




Solution to Question 20:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.
This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.
This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.




Solution to Question 21:

Pain in the early stage of labor is limited to dermatomes T10-L1. This is of uterine origin.
Pain in the late stage of labour is due to dilatation of cervix and perineal stretching. The nerves carrying the pain include S2,3,4.



Solution to Question 22:
True labor pain is not relieved by enema and sedatives. It is characterized by the following:
Painful uterine contractions at regular intervals
The frequency of contractions increases gradually
The intensity and duration of contractions increase progressively
Associated with 'show'- extrusion of the mucus plug that had previously filled the cervical cana during pregnancy
Progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix
Progressive descent of the presenting part
Formation of the 'bag of forewaters' i.e., bulging fluid-filled amniotic membrane presenting in front of the fetal head
Not relieved by enema or sedatives
False labour pain is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.
Such pains are probably due to stretching of the cervix and lower uterine segment with consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.




Solution to Question 23:
The nerve roots blocked in pudendal nerve block are S2,3,4. It is blocked just above the tip of the ischial spine by piercing the sacrospinous ligament.

Pudendal nerve block can be used for:
Analgesia in the second stage of labor
Episiotomy repair
Pelvic floor relaxation for outlet instrument delivery
Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum
Perineal analgesia prior to application of vacuum/forceps
Pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina. It is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation such as manual extraction of the placenta.



Solution to Question 24:
Pain from the lower third of the vagina is relieved by pudendal block, not paracervical block.
Paracervical block relieves the pain of uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. It also relieves pain from upper third of the vagina. It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part of the vagina is not anesthetized.
Note: Paracervical block is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia. Epidural analgesia is preferred when complete relief of pain is needed throughout labour.



Solution to Question 25:
Postdated pregnancy is not an indication for early cord clamping. Early cord clamping is indicated in:
Birth asphyxia
Rh isoimmunization
Diabetic mother
The benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.
On the other hand, delayed cord clamping can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, which increases risks for hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalization for neonatal phototherapy. Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation.
According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord clamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be done even if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping is advised.

Solution to Question 26:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation. Signs of placental separation:
The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)
Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it
Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no onger recedes
A sudden gush of blood
Permanent lengthening of cord
Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine action.
